latest news.eng_title: The six fire-, flood- and storm-prone cities where billionaires love to buy homes
latest news.summary: Despite rising interest rates and natural disasters, billionaires are still buying homes in six cities, according to a report from Realtor.com. The cities are Malibu, San Francisco, Aspen, New York City, Miami, and Palm Beach, all of which have seen sales over $50 million in 2024. The ultra-rich are finding ways to mitigate the risks, such as buying homes with hurricane-proof features, fire suppression systems, and private teams of firefighters. They are also able to pay all-cash or negotiate special deals with banks due to their longstanding relationships and massive holdings. 'For every excuse not to buy, billionaires find a workaround,' the report said.
latest news.title: The six fire-, flood- and storm-prone cities where billionaires love to buy homes

latest news.eng_title: Aliko Dangote Loses Title as Africa's Richest Man to Johann Rupert
latest news.summary: Aliko Dangote, the Nigerian billionaire, has lost his title as the richest man in Africa to Johann Rupert, the South African luxury goods magnate, according to Forbes and Bloomberg's daily rankings of the world's richest people. Dangote, who is the CEO of Dangote Group, ranks 186th globally with a fortune of $11.4 billion, after losing over $486 million in the past three days. Dangote had previously lost billions of dollars due to the strong devaluation of the naira, which began in June 2023. According to Forbes' real-time billionaire rankings, Johann Rupert ranks 175th globally with a fortune of $11.9 billion. Bloomberg's Billionaires Index places Rupert at 146th globally with a fortune of $14.3 billion. The differences between Forbes and Bloomberg's rankings are due to the different methodologies used by the two media outlets to evaluate the wealth of billionaires worldwide. Analysts believe that Dangote's fortune is likely to increase in the coming months, particularly when his oil refinery's production capacity increases with improved crude oil supply and diversified refined products. Dangote Refinery's enterprise value is expected to rise rapidly, considering its quasi-monopoly position on the Nigerian fuel market and its plans to target other African countries.
latest news.title: Aliko Dangote perd encore son titre d'homme le plus riche d'Afrique

latest news.eng_title: South African billionaire overtakes Aliko Dangote as Africa's richest person
latest news.summary: Johann Rupert, chairman of Richemont, has overtaken Aliko Dangote as Africa's richest person, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Rupert's net worth has surged to $14.3 billion, while Dangote's fortune has declined to $13.4 billion due to Nigeria's challenging macroeconomic environment. The Dangote Group has faced production delays and industrial issues at its refinery, compounded by the depreciation of the naira, which has significantly impacted Dangote's wealth. Despite the challenges, the Dangote Group plans to generate $30 billion in revenue by 2025 by expanding its influence in the foreign exchange market.
latest news.title: South African billionaire overtakes Aliko Dangote as Africa's richest person

latest news.eng_title: The American cities where billionaires are purchasing properties - despite well-known risks
latest news.summary: Despite the risks of climate disasters and soaring prices, American billionaires are continuing to purchase luxury properties in desirable locations like Malibu, Palm Beach, and Miami. Industry experts reveal that billionaires are largely immune to typical home-buying hurdles, as they can afford top-tier protection against natural disasters and often own multiple homes to escape extreme weather. Recent high-profile sales highlight this trend, with billionaires like James Jannard, Karlie Kloss, and Jay-Z and Beyoncé buying properties in Malibu. According to Margit Brandt, a real estate agent in Palm Beach, 'The most important factors we see Palm Beach buyers looking for, universally, are one, instant gratification or turnkey products, and two, value.' Brandt also explained that the ultra-rich may not be impacted by hurricane season because they fly down after Thanksgiving. Additionally, places like Malibu are appealing due to its natural beauty and proximity to key industries. Creative financing options also play a role in this luxury market boom, with the ultra-rich able to leverage their assets for competitive loan rates or simply pay cash. Meanwhile, soaring home prices and mortgage rates have sidelined many average homebuyers, with some states seeing declines since last year. The average home price across the country was $442,500 as of May, which is 'relatively stable compared to the same time last year,' according to Realtor.com Chief Economist Danielle Hale.
latest news.title: The American cities where billionaires are purchasing properties - despite well-known risks

latest news.eng_title: Investors on Edge Ahead of Nvidia Earnings and US Economic Data
latest news.summary: Investors are on edge ahead of Nvidia's earnings and US economic data releases. The market saw little movement on Tuesday, with US stock futures and the dollar experiencing minimal changes, while Treasury bond yields rose slightly. Nvidia's weight, with the second-highest weighting in the S&P 500 after Apple Inc., and its high valuation make it susceptible to large swings that could have a significant impact. According to Bloomberg data, options traders see a potential 10% move in either direction after earnings, which would translate to around 160 points in the Nasdaq 100 index or an 0.8% move. Alberto Tocchio, portfolio manager at Kairos Partners, said, 'The numbers from Nvidia will be good, but what matters is the guidance to understand if demand remains healthy.' If there are bad news, the rotation will be even stronger, as the market remains highly concentrated on megacap stocks.'  Economists predict that the personal consumption expenditures price index, excluding food and energy, will rise 0.2% in July for the second consecutive month, bringing the quarterly annualized rate of the so-called underlying inflation to 2.1%, just above the Fed's target of 2%. Volkmar Baur, strategist at Commerzbank AG, said, 'Of course, the central bank will emphasize that it has not yet made a decision and will wrap it in the words 'it depends on the data.' But 95% of what it needs to know for its September meeting should already be available.'
latest news.title: Los inversores están nerviosos ante los resultados de Nvidia y los datos de EEUU

latest news.eng_title: Brazil's Youngest and Oldest Billionaires on the 2024 Forbes List
latest news.summary: Being a billionaire requires not only hard work and competence, but also time. The average age of Brazilian billionaires on the 2024 Forbes list is 62 years old. However, there are extremes. The youngest billionaire is Amelie Voigt Trejes, a Catarinense heir to the WEG company, which is a 'celeiro de bilionários' (a genuine breeding ground for billionaires) with 29 participants on the Forbes list this year. On the other hand, the oldest billionaire is João Jacob Vontobel, a Gaúcho from the Vonpar company.
latest news.title: Lista Forbes Bilionários Brasileiros 2024: a mais nova e o mais experiente

latest news.eng_title: Powell's pivot leaves traders debating rate cut
latest news.summary: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech at the annual symposium in Wyoming has left traders debating the size of the first interest-rate cut and the future path of easing. Powell said 'the time has come' for the Fed to lower benchmark rates from their two-decade high, but gave no indication on the size of cuts or the path of easing. Traders added to bets on a half-point of rate cuts in September, and the weak greenback is emerging as the currency of choice for a new wave of so-called carry trades involving risky bets made with borrowed money. The outlook for lower Fed policy rate has the S&P 500 index up 18% so far in 2024, but a prolonged heightening of geopolitical risk in the Middle East could prompt the S&P 500 to pare gains and bolster the greenback. The next monthly US labour report, due Sept 6, will be crucial in determining the size of the rate cut, with some strategists suggesting that 50 basis points could come into the picture if the next set of jobs data follows the recent softer-than-expected numbers. Bloomberg strategists said, 'Jerome Powell ultimately told us what we already knew, albeit perhaps a little more forcefully than some of his colleagues'. The pivot to cuts is seen as a negative for the US dollar, making it a potentially appealing currency for use in carry trades.
latest news.title: Powell's pivot leaves traders debating rate cut

latest news.eng_title: Luxury Real Estate in the US Sees Record-Breaking Sales
latest news.summary: The luxury real estate market in the United States is on the move again. The sale of a duplex in Central Park, New York for $115 million (nearly $104 million euros) in June has added to the five other transactions above $100 million (nearly $90 million euros) that have taken place so far this year. According to Bloomberg, these six deals are close to the 2021 record of nine transactions that exceeded nine figures. Analysts see this transaction in New York as a turning point in the luxury real estate sector, as just a month later, a five-story penthouse was sold for $135 million in the same area. This activity is due to the fact that millionaires around the world have seen their wealth grow, leading to large real estate purchases. As a result, the sales pace is stimulating optimism among market agents, according to Bloomberg. According to the publication, it is not expected that the pace of luxury business will slow down in the short term. In fact, in Malibu, an agent is preparing to put a mansion on the market in a private listing for $300 million, which would set a record for the most expensive home sale in the United States if it receives an offer at that level, as stated by Bloomberg.
latest news.title: La vivienda de ultralujo en EEUU roza récords: seis ventas de más de 100 millones de dólares

latest news.eng_title: Meta, Zuckerberg: 'Pressure from the White House on COVID-19 content'
latest news.summary: Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Meta, revealed that the company received pressure from the White House to limit content related to the COVID-19 pandemic. In a letter to the US House of Representatives' Justice Committee, Zuckerberg stated that in 2021, high-ranking officials from the Biden administration, including the White House, repeatedly pressured Meta's teams to censor certain COVID-19 content, including satire. Zuckerberg described the pressure as 'wrong' and expressed regret that Meta did not speak out more strongly against it. He emphasized that the company should not compromise its content standards due to pressure from any administration. The article also mentions the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, which lists the richest people in the world, including Donald Trump, who has seen his fortune increase by $500 million since leaving the White House in 2020.
latest news.title: Meta, Zuckerberg: 'Pressioni dalla Casa Bianca sui contenuti Covid'

latest news.eng_title: Bloomberg's Richest Person in the World: Elon Musk Tops the List
latest news.summary: According to Bloomberg, the richest person in the world is Elon Musk, with a net worth of $244 billion. His wealth has increased by $14.6 billion since the beginning of the year. The second place is held by Bernard Arnault, with a net worth of $201 billion, who has lost $6.3 billion since the beginning of the year. Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, is in third place, with a net worth of $200 billion, which has increased by $23.4 billion since January. Mark Zuckerberg and Bill Gates, with net worths of $188 billion and $159 billion respectively, also made it to the top five. In contrast, the richest Ukrainian, Rinat Akhmetov, according to Forbes, has a net worth of $4.4 billion, which has decreased by $1.7 billion since last year. He is followed by Viktor Pinchuk and Konstantin Zhukov, with net worths of $2.2 billion and $1.4 billion respectively.
latest news.title: Кто самый богатый человек мира: рейтинг от Bloomberg — Finance.ua

news knowledge.eng_title: Futures Rise Ahead Of Data Deluge Including Key Retail Sales Report
news knowledge.summary: US equity futures are rising ahead of a data deluge, including a key retail sales report, which may support the case for the Federal Reserve to cut rates at its September meeting. Walmart jumped 7.8% in premarket trading after raising its sales and profit guidance for the full year. Cisco Systems rose after the networking equipment maker's results beat expectations. Mark Haefele, chief investment officer at UBS Global Wealth Management, said, 'The latest US inflation data supports our view of a gradual cooling of the US economy.' The Fed may not reveal its hand until the Sep 6 NFP print. European stocks rise for a third day, led by health care, insurance and technology names, while travel and leisure is falling the most. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index is unchanged; the pound rises 0.1% against the dollar. The Norwegian krone has risen to the top of the G-10 FX leader board, adding 0.4% after a hawkish hold from the Norges Bank.
news knowledge.title: Futures Rise Ahead Of Data Deluge Including Key Retail Sales Report

news knowledge.eng_title: Top 10 Richest People in the US, the World Billionaire
news knowledge.summary: Forbes Magazine has reported that there are 813 American billionaires with a combined net worth of $5.7 trillion as of 2024. Elon Musk was named the richest person in the United States in 2024 by Forbes Magazine as his net worth reached $195 billion. According to Forbes Magazine, the top 10 richest people in the US in 2024 are: 1. Elon Musk - $195 Billion, 2. Jeff Bezos - $194 Billion, 3. Mark Zuckerberg - $177 Billion, 4. Larry Ellison - $141 billion, 5. Warren Buffet - $133 Billion, 6. Bill Gates - $128 Billion, 7. Steeve Ballmer - $121 Billion, 8. Larry Page - $114 Billion, 9. Sergey Brin - $110 Billion, and 10. Michael Bloomberg - $106 Billion. These American billionaires are among the top 12 richest men in the world, according to Forbes magazine.
news knowledge.title: Top 10 Richest People in U.S., the World Billionaire

news knowledge.eng_title: Bloomberg Publishes New Billionaires Index: Americans Dominate Top Three
news knowledge.summary: Bloomberg has published the 'Billionaires Index', which is calculated based on the value of companies' shares. According to the data, Bernard Arnault, the owner of LVMH, is no longer in the top three most wealthy people in the world, and only Americans are in the top three. Elon Musk remains the leader of the ranking with a net worth of $235 billion. Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, continues to hold the second place with a net worth of $193 billion. Mark Zuckerberg, the head of Meta, takes the third place with a net worth of $188 billion. Bernard Arnault has dropped to the fourth place with assets worth $184 billion. Thus, the top three wealthiest people in the world are citizens of the United States. However, Arnault is the only non-American in the top ten. Bloomberg has been publishing the Bloomberg Billionaires Index since March 2012, and it includes information on the state of 500 of the richest people on the planet.
news knowledge.title: Агентство Bloomberg опубликовало новый рейтинг миллиардеров: в тройке лидеров — американцы

news knowledge.eng_title: Bloomberg's Billionaires Index: Elon Musk Remains at the Top
news knowledge.summary: Bloomberg's 'Billionaires Index' has been published, and it shows that Bernard Arnault, the owner of LVMH, is no longer in the top three of the richest people in the world. The list is dominated by Americans, with Elon Musk, the owner of X and Tesla, remaining at the top with a net worth of $235 billion. Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, is in second place with a net worth of $193 billion. Mark Zuckerberg, the CEO of Meta, has risen to third place with a net worth of $188 billion. Bernard Arnault has fallen to fourth place with a net worth of $184 billion, making him the only non-American in the top ten. According to the index, 'the trio of the richest people in the world consists of citizens of the United States.'
news knowledge.title: Bloomberg опубликовал рейтинг богатейших людей мира

news knowledge.eng_title: US Consumer Price Index Data Expected to Show Soft Inflation
news knowledge.summary: After the mild inflation rate, swap traders priced in a potential 40 basis point Fed rate cut in September and over 100 basis points in total for 2024. The S&P 500 index rose 1.7% led by technology stocks. Treasury bonds generally gained value, with short-term bonds experiencing increased activity and the yield on the 10-year US Treasury bond falling 6 basis points to 3.84%. The Bloomberg Dollar Index reached its lowest level since April, while Brent oil paused its five-day rally and fell 2% yesterday. Asian stock markets were mixed this morning, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rising for the fourth consecutive day, driven by gains of over 1% in New Zealand and Taiwan. Japanese stocks and the yen were volatile due to political uncertainty. Today, the US is expected to release its consumer price index (CPI) data, which is expected to remain at 3% year-over-year, with core CPI expected to fall to 3.2% from 3.3%. According to Bloomberg's Chief Economist Anna Wong, 'We expect the July CPI to be soft due to reduced consumer spending, a slowdown in housing rents, a decline in used car prices, and discounts in discretionary services.' Wong also noted that if their predictions are correct, the July CPI data, combined with the soft June inflation rate, could indicate that the core PCE deflator is accelerating year-over-year. Wong added, 'This would not prevent the Fed from cutting rates by 50 basis points at their September meeting. We expect the Fed to focus more on the employment side of their dual mandate as the unemployment rate is expected to rise to 4.5% by October.'
news knowledge.title: Küresel piyasaların gözü ABD'nin TÜFE verisinde!

news knowledge.eng_title: US PPI Data Strengthens Expectations of a September Rate Cut
news knowledge.summary: The recent release of the US Producer Price Index (PPI) has strengthened expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve (Fed) in September, leading to a rise in Wall Street indexes and a decline in bond yields. Swap traders have priced in a 40 basis point Fed rate cut in September and over 100 basis points of rate cuts for 2024. The S&P 500 index rose 1.7% led by the stocks of the world's largest technology companies. Treasury yields rose across the curve, with the 10-year US Treasury yield falling 6 basis points to 3.84%. The Bloomberg Dollar Index reached its lowest level since April. Brent oil prices declined 2% after a five-day rally, influenced by the tensions in the Middle East. Asian stock markets are mixed, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rising for the fourth consecutive day, driven by gains of over 1% in New Zealand and Taiwan. Japanese stocks and the yen were affected by political uncertainty. The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) data will be released today at 15:30 CEST. Bloomberg's US Chief Economist Anna Wong expects a soft CPI reading due to slowing consumer spending, a decline in housing rents, and a decrease in used car prices. However, the core PCE deflator is expected to show a more complex picture. Wong stated, 'If our forecast is correct, the CPI data, combined with the soft June inflation reading, would suggest that the core PCE deflator accelerated year-over-year in July.' She added, 'This would likely keep the FOMC from cutting rates by 50 basis points at the September meeting. Instead, the Fed will focus more on the labor market, which is expected to rise to 4.5% by the end of the year, likely in October.'
news knowledge.title: Küresel piyasalarda gündem ABD TÜFE verisi! İşte detaylar...

news knowledge.eng_title: Bernard Arnault Loses More Wealth Than Any Other Billionaire in 2024
news knowledge.summary: Bernard Arnault, the French billionaire and CEO of LVMH, saw his net worth decline by more than any other person in 2024, according to the Bloomberg's Billionaires Index, as luxury goods demand continues to decrease. Arnault's fortune fell by 20 billion dollars to 187 billion dollars, surpassing the accumulated losses of China's richest man, Zhong Shanshan. Elon Musk, the world's richest person, suffered a larger one-day loss, but still increased his wealth by 5% this year. Despite the decline, Musk remains ahead of Jeff Bezos by 37 billion dollars. Arnault, 75, fell to third place after being the world's richest person last month, a position he held after the pandemic when global luxury goods demand surged. Zhong is at risk of losing his top spot in China due to intensified competition and public relations challenges at his bottled water giant, Nongfu Spring Co.
news knowledge.title: Bernard Arnault perdeu mais patrimônio do que qualquer outro multimilionário em 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: Wealth of Luxury Goods Billionaires Declines Globally
news knowledge.summary: The wealth of billionaires in the luxury goods sector has declined globally this year due to a slowdown in demand for those products and beauty products in some regions. According to the 'Bloomberg' billionaires index, the wealth of six billionaires who rely on expensive and luxurious products decreased by 5% this year, or around $24 billion. On the other hand, the wealth of the remaining 500 people included in the index increased by 13%, or $1 trillion. The French billionaire Bernard Arnault, 75, and founder of 'LVMH', lost $10.8 billion since the beginning of this year, reaching $197 billion, and becoming the third richest person in the world after Elon Musk, founder of 'Tesla', and Jeff Bezos, founder of 'Amazon'. Earlier this month, Françoise Bettencourt Meyers, heir to the large cosmetics company 'L'Oréal', briefly lost her title as the richest woman in the world to Alice Walton, member of the founding family of the American retail group 'Walmart'.
news knowledge.title: تراجع ثروات مليارديرات «السلع الفخمة»

news knowledge.eng_title: Five things you need to know for Thursday, July 11
news knowledge.summary: The US inflation data (CPI) will be released on Thursday, July 11, as investors seek clues for a potential interest rate cut in September. Yesterday, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell told Congress that the central bank does not need inflation to be below 2% before cutting rates, and noted that the labor market has cooled 'significantly'. Investors will also be watching company earnings reports from Delta and PepsiCo, seeking signs about the health of US consumers before the quarterly reports from JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup. Here are five highlights for Thursday: The main event of the day is the release of the US consumer price index (CPI) in the morning. Analysts expect the data to show the smallest consecutive increases in core inflation since mid-July last year, strengthening the case for a rate cut by the Federal Reserve in September. The expectation is for a 0.2% increase in the core index for June, for the second consecutive month. The broader index is expected to show a smaller 0.1% increase, partly due to lower gasoline prices. A result like this would help solidify projections that the Fed will start cutting rates in September, marking the first step in reversing its most aggressive tightening campaign since the 1980s. Meanwhile, in Brazil, the focus is on retail sales data for May. Median estimate in a Bloomberg survey points to a 4.4% annual increase, following a 2.2% increase in the previous month. The monthly index is expected to show a 0.5% decline, according to projections. Global stocks rose on Wednesday, as traders prepare for a potential rate cut by the Federal Reserve. US futures signaled a continuation of the S&P 500's rally, which reached its 36th record this year. The Euro Stoxx 600 was up 0.6% at 8:15 am (Brasília time), while S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 futures rose 0.3%, as traders analyzed comments from Fed Chairman Jerome Powell on the US economy.
news knowledge.title: Cinco coisas que você precisa saber para começar esta quinta-feira, 11 de julho

news knowledge.eng_title: US CPI may cement September Fed cut: this week's playbook
news knowledge.summary: The article discusses the potential for the US CPI to cement a September Fed cut, as well as the impact of French politics on the EUR. The US data flow has been deteriorating, with the Bloomberg US growth surprise index at its weakest levels since May 2020. The article also discusses the potential for a soft landing scenario, where the Fed eases to massage the fed funds rate away from a restrictive setting, and the implications for bonds, equity, and gold. The article also mentions the upcoming US CPI inflation print, which could impact market expectations of a rate cut. Additionally, the article discusses the upcoming earnings season, with major banks reporting on Friday, and the potential for a retest of $2400 in gold.
news knowledge.title: US CPI may cement September Fed cut: this week's playbook
